Award.AwardTitle: Measurement of Large Freeform Optics using a Small and High-Precision Sensor

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Using freeform optics, the optical industry can provide compact, efficient, and high performance optical products with many unique features that allow reduction in both the number and size of lenses in an optical system. These products have wide applications including scientific research, solar energy harvest, medical, and military applications. However, manufacturing of freeform optics today relies on the "trial and error" approach due to the lack of efficient metrology to measure freeform optical surfaces during and after they are manufactured. This award supports fundamental research to provide knowledge that is needed to develop a new freeform optics measurement system that can measure freeform optical surfaces efficiently. The new measurement system will provide US companies a competitive edge and can lead to innovations in telecommunication, aerospace, consumer electronics, automotive, and medical industries.

The new freeform optical metrology is based on subaperture measurements using a small and high-precision Shack-Hartmann wavefront sensor. These measurements are then combined using novel stitching methods to reconstruct the entire freeform optical surface. The first research objective is to establish the dependence of each stitching method on the system design. Each stitching method will be characterized by its convergence rate and corresponding residual error. The design parameters include aperture size, shape, and selection of Zernike polynomial terms. To achieve this objective, experiments on an Alvarez lens will be performed by changing the subaperture size between 10-100 percent of the full aperture. In addition, a square and a sphere shape subaperture will be tested, and up to 7 Zernike polynomial terms will be used in the experiments. The second research objective is to establish the relationship between the dynamic performance of the system and microlens design and lens array configuration used in the Shack-Hartmann sensor. In experimental investigations, microlens parameters (including f-number and lens geometry) and lens array configuration (including non-uniform lens layout and arbitrary base curve where the microlenses reside) will be varied; dynamic performance of the system will be evaluated in terms of degree of slop change, measurement time, and measurement accuracy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The idea of freeform optics is considered a revolution in both optical design and manufacturing. A freeform surface in optical design and fabrication is broadly defined as a surface that is not rotationally symmetric. Although these surfaces are called freeform, they are in fact mathematically determinant. Unlike conventional optics, freeform optical elements are often used in a variety of one-of-a-kind scientific instruments, but occasionally are also used in mass-produced consumer products, such as heads-up displays, virtual and augmented reality devices, solar panels, progressive addition spectacle lenses, and telescope mirrors, to name just a few.

Freeform optics is revolutionizing the optical industry by providing compact, efficient and high performance products. As a critical part of freeform optics technology, freeform metrology is the least studied area. In this research program, interdisciplinary research in freeform metrology based on subaperture wavefront measurement using a Shack-Hartmann sensor is proposed. The core contribution of this research is to develop the capability to reconstruct a precision freeform surface from multiple individual subaperture measurements, in which the overall surface can be much larger than the individual measurement subapertures. To our knowledge, this is the first attempt at this type of metrology based on an SHS system. The anticipated results of this project will be accessible and exciting to our students, thereby providing a compelling classroom experience through demonstrations and presentations.

  • Construct a noncontact ultraprecision freeform measurement system, based on subaperture sensing using a Shack-Hartmann sensor.
  • Understand and model the Shack-Hartmann sensor based subaperture measurement system.
  • Develop a freeform optics fabrication strategy based on the subaperture freeform optics measurement system

This research will establish the fundamental scientific understanding required for a freeform optical metrology system based on subaperture measurements using a Shack-Hartmann sensor. We propose to use Zernike polynomials for freeform surface reconstruction using novel stitching methods. Zernike series are well-suited for this purpose for their stability and fast convergence as compared to, for example, Taylor series. Efforts also include system calibration, analysis of measurement errors, and study of the dynamic performance of the system using different Shack-Hartmann sensor microlens configurations. The Signal-to-noise ratio and its impact on freeform measurement accuracy will be carefully studied. Finally, the proposed freeform metrology system can be retrofitted into an ultraprecision machining center to validate system performance using freeform elements. Because the method is noncontact, it provides submicron precision with dynamic performance allowing in situ measurements of large and complex freeform features. It can also measure refractive optics thus can cover almost the entire process chain of optical fabrication today.
